conclusion: The problem involves a rotating metal shaft and rod in a magnetic field, affecting a voltmeter reading.
The image shows a metal shaft \( O O' \) rotating with a rod \( M \) sliding on a ring \( N \), connected to a voltmeter \( V \).
The voltmeter reading is determined by the induced voltage, which depends on the magnetic field and angular velocity.
Initially, the magnetic induction intensity is \( B_0 \), and the angular velocity is \( \omega_0 \), resulting in a voltmeter reading of \( U_0 \).
When the magnetic induction intensity changes to \( nB_0 \), the voltmeter reading needs to be \( mU_0 \).
The induced voltage \( U \) is proportional to both the magnetic induction intensity \( B \) and the angular velocity \( \omega \): \( U \propto B\omega \).
This new angular velocity ensures the voltmeter reading \( mU_0 \) when the magnetic field is \( nB_0 \).
